snippet: Young adults in Iran who came of age after the revolution have resigned themselves to making the best of a bad situation.
abstract: Tehran Journal; Iranians who were born after the 1979 revolution have resigned themselves to making the best of a bad situation; calling themselves the 'burned generation', they feel their ambitions have been boxed in by the political decisions of Iran's leaders and the foreign pressures that followed. Photo (M)

byline.original: By THOMAS ERDBRINK; Ramtin Rastin and Somaye Malekian contributed reporting

lead_paragraph: TEHRAN -- About two months ago, when many Iranian families were stocking up on rice and meat to prepare for seemingly inevitable military conflict with the West over Iran's nuclear program, Ali Mesgaran, 35, decided to open a sandwich shop. Iran's national currency, the rial, had just lost nearly half of its value amid new international sanctions, and banks and exchange offices were spilling over with orders for gold and foreign currency from people hoping to protect family savings from soaring inflation.

headline.main: Pinched Aspirations of Iran's Young Multitudes
